ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: RNA seq data analysis and using R as a language to organize, analyze, and visualize data.
Start to end how to perform RNA-seq analysis
I learned about analyzing RNA sequencing data. The class taught us how to develop a computational pipeline from start to end.
I learned the fundamentals of RNA-Seq and introductory coding in R and bash.
This class teaches the basics of R that lead you to conduct RNA sequencing analysis. You learn through online tutorials and mini scripts.
Transcriptomics and key principles of RNA-seq analysis
Knowledge of different tools used for RNAseq analysis to filter, trim, align, and analyze reads using the cluster.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the final assignment is a strength, it really helps you bring all the concepts together and give you an opportunity to realize how useful these tools are. Datacamp was very useful too, definitely another strength, no need to worry about the grade, just learn, since the exercises are graded completion based. For the weaknesses, I feel like I was lost at many times during the semester, and there was a lot of self learning and Google. However, I understand that's the best way to learn for this types of concepts. If you are really stuck just ask for help and you'll get it.
I think one way the class could be improved would be more in class examples of code.
I wish there were more exercises in addition to the weekly Datacamp.

This class has access to DataCamp which helps to practice and learn bash and R. The class does a good job of giving a ground-up understanding of RNA sequencing analysis, but maybe more time could be spent on the analysis part of the course since this felt more glossed over.

Very well constructured learnings and lots of support from teaching staff - only weakness would be additional assignments and attention paid to elements of pipeline following DESeq. I think the course could have benefitted from additional work in DESeq visualizations as well as functional annotations, getting into GSEA particularly.

I learned far better by doing exercises in the cluster rather than watching data camp videos. Essentially the entirety of the DESeq workflow was taught through these data camp videos and the first time I had really done a full analysis was for the final project which was a big task for me and many of my classmates. 
I really loved the flexibility of this class and the option to complete work on our own time. This allowed me to move through the lab activities at my own pace because it can be hard to sit through a lab for 4+ hours with good focus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Definitely useful stuff if you are planning on doing anything bio related. Also a very different experience from the regular lab that everyone is already used to. And the professor is extremely sweet and knowledgeable!

Yes. Its not too much weekly work and the final project was difficult but I realized that I learned a lot about the basics of RNA-Seq. Take the course if youre interested in becoming more proficient in bash and R in a biological context.
I would recommend as an MCDB lab that doesnt take a lot of time, is a credit, and is probably more useful than most other MCDB lab courses. I have found it useful in my own research.
Yes, key understanding for anyone interested in biology research. RNA-seq and transcriptomics/bioinformatics will be a part of every researcher's work going forward.

I think this was a great lab course for bio people looking to gain some computational skills. I would just recommend going to office hours and really trying to engage with the data camp videos because that portion of the course was the hardest to learn.
